Synthesis and electromagnetic wave absorption performance of NiCo2O4 nanomaterials with different nanostructures†
Qinghai Zhu, Zilong Zhang, * Yangyang Lv, Xiqiao Chen, Zhuang Wu, Shuai Wang and Yanhong Zou*
Bayberry-like, needle array-like and urchin-like NiCo2O4 hierarchical structures were synthesized by simple hydrothermal reactions. The differences among the nanostructures and morphologies affecting their
electromagnetic wave absorbing properties have been systematically studied. Benefiting from the unique
hierarchical structures assembled by magnetic component units, all of these NiCo2O4 nanomaterials show satisfactory performances of absorbing microwave radiation. Remarkably, the urchin-like NiCo2O4 obtains an optimum reflection loss (RL) value of −40 dB when the matching thickness is only 1.4 mm. Moreover, the urchin-like NiCo2O4 reaches an effective absorbing bandwidth of about 15 GHz upon adjustment of the coating thickness. The outstanding electromagnetic wave absorbing properties are closely related to
the strong interfacial polarization, dipole relaxation, eddy current loss and multiple reflections in its unique
needle-like assembly.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Along with the widespread popularity of electronic communication equipment in the military, civil and commercial fields, the negative impact of electromagnetic interference on information security and human health has attracted great attention.1–4 Therefore, it is imperative to develop a lightweight, ultra-thin and highly efficient electromagnetic wave absorber, which can convert electromagnetic energy into heat energy by dielectric and magnetic loss.5–8 As traditional electromagnetic wave absorbers, composite materials containing a dielectric component and a magnetic component such as Co@C,9 CoFe2O4/CNTs, 10 and Fe3O4@C 11 are favored by researchers for their high oxidation resistance, strong interfacial polarization and electromagnetic energy loss ability. Unfortunately, these structures composed of multiple components usually suffer from some disadvantages such as a high cost, complex preparation and easy agglomeration. Consequently, the preparation of absorbers formed from mono-component units can be considered as a facile strategy to further analyze the absorbing mechanism of electromagnetic waves.12–14
According to previous studies, the geometry and microstructure of single component absorbers have a significant influence on their microwave absorption characteristics.15–17 Generally, designing porous structures is a feasible method to reduce the density and improve the impedance matching as well as the attenuation performance of electromagnetic wave absorbers.18–21 Besides, the electromagnetic wave absorbing materials assembled from nanocrystalline components usually possess better electromagnetic wave absorbing properties, which are attributed to their superiority such as high electron mobility, strong interfacial polarization and dipole relaxation.22,23 Recently, some great progress has been achieved in electromagnetic wave absorption based on the abovementioned structures. For example, Ji et al. synthesized porous 3D flower-like Co/CoO through an annealing treatment at 400 °C.24 Benefiting from its ultra-thin flake assemblies, the minimum RL value of Co/CoO reaches −25 dB at a thickness of 3 mm. Analogously, a porous α-Fe2O3@CoFe2O4 microsphere structure composed of coin-like nanosheets was successfully synthesized by Lv et al.25 When the coating thickness is 2.5 mm, the α-Fe2O3@CoFe2O4 absorber obtains an optimum RL value of −41 dB at a frequency of 13.8 GHz. Besides, a hollow Fe3O4 hemisphere was prepared by Zou et al. via a hydrothermal and calcination process.26 Due to the strong interfacial polarization and eddy current loss in its unique bowl-like structure, a minimum RL value of −31.2 dB was achieved when the thickness is 3.5 mm. Thus, it could be concluded that well-designed morphologies and nanostructures

Spinel NiCo2O4 nanomaterials have attracted considerable attention for electrochemical energy storage, catalysts and transparent conductive films due to their various advantages such as porous structures, easy preparation and good stability.27–29 In addition, NiCo2O4 fibers,
30 NiCo2O4 nanospheres31 and hierarchical NiCo2O4/Co3O4/NiO composites 32 have been synthesized as electromagnetic wave absorbers. However, these NiCo2O4 materials suffer from some shortcomings such as their weak absorption effects, large matching thicknesses and filler loadings, which limit their wide application in the field of microwave absorption.
Herein, a series of NiCo2O4 materials with hierarchical structures were synthesized by simple hydrothermal reaction and calcination processes. Compared with the abovementioned NiCo2O4 materials, the bayberry-like, needle arraylike and urchin-like NiCo2O4 nanomaterials using single crystal components as self-assembled units can obtain more excellent electromagnetic wave absorption performance. Herein, the urchin-like NiCo2O4 nanomaterial achieves a minimum RL value of −40 dB when the thickness is as thin as 1.4 mm and its efficient absorbing range is from 14 to 18 GHz, which can be attributed to the occurrence of electron accumulation, eddy current loss and dipole relaxation around the abundant interface areas resulting from its novel needle cluster structure. Thus, our work may provide a feasible method for synthesizing ultra-thin, highly efficient and morphology-controlled electromagnetic wave absorbers and designing new guidelines toward advanced hierarchical structures based on NiCo2O4 nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 2.1. Synthesis of bayberry-like NiCo2O4
sections.text: On the basis of previous methods,33 NiCo2O4 nanomaterials with a bayberry-like morphology were successfully synthesized. Typically, 1 mmol of NiĲNO3)2·6H2O, 2 mmol of CoĲNO3)2·6H2O, 30 mmol of NH4HCO3 and 10 mmol of urea were added into a mixed solution (50 ml ethylene glycol and 10 ml deionized water) and then stirred vigorously for 30 minutes until the solution turned clear. The solution was then poured into a Teflon lined stainless steel autoclave (100 ml) and kept at 200 °C for 24 hours. Next, a precipitate was obtained which was washed with deionized water several times and then dried in an oven under air at 60 °C for 48 hours. Finally, the sample was calcined under a pure N2 atmosphere at the same temperature (350 °C) for 2 h with a heating rate of 1 °C min−1.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of nanoneedle array NiCo2O4
sections.text: Based on the synthesis of bayberry-like NiCo2O4, the nanoneedle array NiCo2O4 material was synthesized by changing the mixed solution and additive to 60 ml of deionized water and 15 mmol of urea, respectively. In addition, the hydrothermal reaction time was adjusted to 12 hours at 120 °C.

sections.heading: 2.3. Synthesis of urchin-like NiCo2O4
sections.text: Similar to the synthesis method of nanoneedle array NiCo2O4, the NiCo2O4 nanomaterial with an urchin-like morphology was synthesized by changing the additive (15 mmol of urea) to 3 wt% Pluronic-123 and 15 mmol of urea.

sections.heading: 2.4. Characterization
sections.text: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi S-480) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL-JEM2100) were performed to analyze the morphologies and structures of the NiCo2O4 nanomaterials. The crystal phases of the NiCo2O4 nanomaterials were observed using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Model D8 ADVANCE) with Cu Kα X-ray radiation. The composition and valence of elements of the prepared NiCo2O4 nanomaterials were determined using an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS, ESCALAB 250Xi). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas were determined with a Tri-Star 3020 system. Paraffin wax and the NiCo2O4 nanomaterials were mixed homogeneously at a filler loading of 45%, and the mixtures were pressed into an annular shape with a size of 7.0 × 3.0 × 2.0 mm. The electromagnetic parameters of the as-prepared products were obtained using a network analyzer (CETC41 AV3629) at 2–18 GHz.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
As shown in Scheme 1, the morphology and nanostructure of the NiCo2O4 materials can be significantly affected by the hydrothermal synthesis conditions such as temperature, pressure, solvent type and pH value. Typically, the formation mechanism of the needle array-like NiCo2O4 nanomaterial can be explained as follows. Initially, a strong alkaline environment was obtained due to the decomposition of urea in aqueous solution. With the increase of reaction temperature and system pressure, small NiCo2ĲOH)6 nuclei were formed by the coordination of cobalt ions, nickel ions and hydroxide ions.33 Subsequently, benefiting from the decrease of interfacial free energy, the NiCo2ĲOH)6 nuclei gradually grew into needle-like nanocrystalline units. Then, these needle-like units are further self-assembled by the interaction of noncovalent bonds to form an array structure. After annealing the obtained NiCo2ĲOH)6 precursors, needle array-like NiCo2O4 nanomaterials with a hierarchical porous structure were successfully synthesized. In addition, with the polymerization of Pluronic-123, the NiCo2ĲOH)6 nuclei can be transformed into needle cluster assembly units and further form urchin-like structures. By increasing the reaction temperature and the concentration of hydroxide ions, the growth rate of the crystal was increased. Therefore, bayberry-like NiCo2O4 particles with a larger grain size were successfully obtained.
The SEM images of the NiCo2O4 nanomaterials with different nanostructures, the bayberry-like, needle array-like and urchin-like, are shown in Fig. 1. When the hydrothermal reaction solvent is ethylene glycol and water, the bayberry-like NiCo2O4 composed of rod-like nanoparticle units is

By changing the solvent and additive into pure water and urea, the stubby and relatively disorganized needlelike assembly is spliced into a needle array-like NiCo2O4 microstructure with large surface areas (Fig. 1c and d). With the promotion of Pluronic-123, the nanoneedle cluster structure can be further grown and assembled into the urchin-like morphology with a size of 2–3 microns, as shown in Fig. 1e and f. Because of the dense distribution of nanoneedle clusters, the specific surface areas of the NiCo2O4 particles are significantly increased.
The morphologies and crystalline phases of these NiCo2O4 nanomaterials are analyzed using their TEM patterns. As shown in Fig. S1,† the non-smooth surface of a bayberry-like NiCo2O4 particle is formed by the stacking of many nanorod units. By comparing Fig. 2 and S1† in detail, it can be found that the nanoneedle assembly on the surface of the array-like NiCo2O4 structure is relatively stubby and consists of numerous single crystal particles with a diameter of 12 nm, while the needle clusters present on the surface of the urchin-like NiCo2O4 nanomaterials are made up of many single crystal nanoparticles with a small diameter (∼9 nm). Fig. 3 shows the powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the three NiCo2O4 nanomaterials with different morphologies. The two strong peaks at 36.8° and 65.0° can correspond to the (311) and (440) crystal planes of the spinel structure. In addition, the relatively weak peaks of (111), (220), (222), (400), (422), (511) and (533) appeared at 18.9°, 31.2°, 38.3°,44.6°, 55.4°, 59.1° and 77.0°, respectively, which also coincided with the standard diffractogram of NiCo2O4 materials.34 The stronger and sharper diffraction peak of the bayberry-like NiCo2O4 at 36.8° indicates that its crystallinity has been improved. This is further verified by calculating the crystallinities of the bayberry-like, needle array-like and urchin-like NiCo2O4 nanomaterials which are 25.51%, 18.99% and 8.66%, respectively. In addition, based on the Scherrer equation, it can be found that the grain sizes of the bayberrylike, nanoneedle array-like and urchin-like NiCo2O4 nanomaterials are 14.9 nm, 12.4 nm and 9.4 nm, respectively. Therefore, it can be seen that these NiCo2O4 nanomaterials have been successfully synthesized.
Fig. 4 and S2† show the states of the Ni, Co, and O elements on the surface layer of the NiCo2O4 nanomaterials through XPS. In Fig. 4a and S2(a and d),† the fitting peaks at 856.3 and 874.1 eV can be assigned to the valence state of Ni3+, and the peak at 853.9 eV also indicates the valence state containing Ni2+. The peaks designated as jittery satellite peaks can likewise occur at 861.7 and 880.1 eV. The above results indicate that Ni 2p spectrum can be deconvoluted into two spin–orbit binary stars. Similarly, the fitting peaks at 787.9 and 804.8 eV in the Co 2p spectrum (Fig. 4b and S2(b and e)†) correspond to the jittery satellite peaks,35 while the peaks at 778.9 and 794.6 eV, and 782.3 and 798.2 eV indicate that the valence states of the Co element in NiCo2O4 nanomaterials are +3 and +2 (Co3+and Co2+) respectively. In Fig. 4c and S2(c and f),† the binding energy peaks of the oxygen spectrum at 529.4 eV and 530.6 eV generally indicate the
presence of metal–oxygen bonds and the hydroxyl groups respectively, while the peak at the highest binding energy (531.7 eV) is referred to the defect sites with a low oxygen coordination.35 To sum up, XPS further shows that the Ni, Co and O elements in the synthesized electromagnetic wave absorbers exhibit various valence states.
The porous properties of the NiCo2O4 materials were studied by plotting N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms. Fig. 5 and S3† show that these NiCo2O4 nanomaterials exhibit a typical type-IV isotherm. When the value of P/P0 (relative pressure) is in the range of 0.65–1.0, the desorption amount of N2 is larger than the adsorption amount, which indicates that these NiCo2O4 particles have a mesoporous structure. Based on the BJH method, the average pore sizes of the bayberry-like, nanoneedle array-like and urchin-like NiCo2O4 nanomaterials are about 14.33 nm, 21.03 nm and 12.17 nm, respectively. The specific surface areas of the three NiCo2O4 materials are 10.62 m2 g−1, 40.06 m2 g−1 and 62.89 m2 g−1, respectively. Benefiting from their large specific surface areas, the polarization relaxation capability is enhanced by the increase of the electric dipole moment in the interface.36,37 As a result, the NiCo2O4 nanomaterials with special morphologies are conducive to the efficient absorption of incident electromagnetic waves. Additionally, their porous structure is beneficial for the excellent impedance matching and low density of materials, realizing the scattering and multiple reflection of electromagnetic waves.38 Benefiting from the strong microwave neutralization effect of the porous materials, electromagnetic energy can also be highly effectively attenuated. Therefore, these NiCo2O4 materials possess great potential for practical applications.
Fig. 6 shows the variations of complex permittivity (εr = ε′ − jε″) and permeability (μr = μ′ − jμ″) with the frequency for these NiCo2O4 nanomaterials. In general, the storage capacity of electromagnetic energy is represented by the real parts (ε′ and μ′) of the electromagnetic parameters, while the electromagnetic energy loss is closely related to the imaginary parts (ε″ and μ″).39 Therefore, it is of great significance to study the electromagnetic parameters to understand the electromagnetic wave absorbing performance. The real parts of the complex permittivity of these NiCo2O4 nanomaterials show a clear downtrend with increasing frequency, which is described by the Debye relaxation.40 In addition, benefiting from the strong interfacial polarization, dipole relaxation and multiple reflections in their unique needle cluster assembly, the ε′ values of the needle array and urchin-like NiCo2O4 nanomaterials have strong and broad peaks in the range of 2–8 GHz and 11–18 GHz respectively, while that of the bayberry-like NiCo2O4 fluctuates around 13 GHz. In Fig. 6a and b, the ε″ values of the bayberry-like and needle array NiCo2O4 nanomaterials have resonance peaks at frequencies of 7.8, 13.2 and 17 GHz. Compared with these, the ε″ values of the urchin-like NiCo2O4 exhibit a stronger and wider resonant peak in the range of 12–18 GHz (Fig. 6c). Generally, there are a large number of electric dipoles and heterogeneous interfaces in the self-assembled materials. Under the

Hence, these resonance peaks can be attributed to dipole relaxation and interfacial polarization.41 Fig. 6 also indicates that the real parts of permeability (μ′) of these NiCo2O4 materials is basically stable around 1.0, while the imaginary part of permeability exhibits some obvious peaks in the entire bandwidth. The μ″ value of the urchin-like NiCo2O4 varies in the range of 0.5 to −0.2 and displays many wide resonance peaks in the range of 2–8 GHz. Therefore, it can be inferred that the urchin-like NiCo2O4 can exhibit stronger magnetic loss capability.
In addition, the interfacial polarization and Debye dipole relaxation, as two effective mechanisms of dielectric loss, are of great significance for the in-depth study of complex permittivity. According to the Debye equation,41 the relationship between ε' and ε" is explained via the following formula:42
(ε′ − ε∞)2 + (ε″)2 = (εs − ε∞)2 (1)
where εs is the static complex permittivity and ε∞ is the optical complex permittivity. According to the above formula, each semicircle in the relation curve of ε′–ε″ corresponds to a relaxation process. Fig. 7a–c and S4† show the ε′–ε″ curves of the NiCo2O4 nanomaterials with different morphologies and structures. As can be seen from Fig. 7a–c, there are multiple
semicircles in the ε′–ε″ curves of the NiCo2O4 nanomaterials, which suggest the existence of multiple Debye relaxation.43,44 As one of the effective loss mechanisms, the abundant defects and heterogeneous interfaces existing in the assembly components are conducive to the accumulation of electrons and can significantly enhance the polarization relaxation process. In addition, due to the difference in the electronegativity of atoms, the intrinsic dipoles and defect dipoles present in the NiCo2O4 nanomaterials can undergo dipole polarization relaxation with the effect of alternating electric field, which is also beneficial to the improvement of dielectric loss capability. Moreover, a large number of pores and specific surface areas are formed in the process of assembling the crystal component units; thereby, a NiCo2O4 material with an assembled hierarchical structure can realize the multiple reflection and scattering of incident electromagnetic waves. To sum up, the strong interfacial polarization and dipole relaxation further reinforce the dielectric loss capability.45

By increasing the imaginary part of the dielectric constant, the larger the σ value, the stronger the contribution of conduction current to dielectric loss capability. Benefiting from the connection between the component units and the spinel structures with metal ions of various valence states filling in the gaps of oxygen ions, these bayberry-like, needle array-like and urchin-like NiCo2O4 materials provide more paths for electron hopping and directional transmission, which promote the dissipation of electromagnetic energy. Therefore, the excellent dielectric loss capability can be explained by the strong polarization relaxation and conduction loss of these NiCo2O4 materials. Generally, as one of the primary mechanisms of electromagnetic wave absorption, research on the source of complex permeability is also crucial. Fig. 7d and S5 show the frequency-dependent characteristic of the μ″(μ′)−2f −1 value in the whole frequency range. The μ″(μ′)−2f −1 value is approximately a fixed value in the range of 11–18 GHz. These results show that the eddy current loss can be considered as the main source of complex permeability in the high frequency band.47 When the frequency
range is 2–11 GHz, the μ″(μ′)−2f −1 value fluctuates significantly with the frequency; thereby, natural resonance exerts a dominant effect in the low frequency band.48 Because the grain sizes of the three NiCo2O4 materials are all about 12 nm, the positions of their natural resonance peaks are very similar as shown in Fig. 7d.55 Moreover, the intensity of natural resonance represents the magnitude of magnetic loss,49 and the significant change of μ″(μ′)−2f −1 value indicates that natural resonance has a great contribution to the strong electromagnetic wave absorption performance of the NiCo2O4 nanomaterials.
In order to better analyze the performance of these NiCo2O4 electromagnetic wave absorbers, Fig. 8a–c show the dependence of RL values on frequency by using the transmission line theory:50,51

Fig. 8 suggests that the microwave absorbing properties of these NiCo2O4 nanomaterials with different self-assembled structures are obviously different. When the matching thickness is 2.5 mm, the bayberry-like NiCo2O4 obtains an optimum RL value of −39 dB and its qualified absorbing bandwidth is about 3 GHz (Fig. 8a), which can be attributed to its appropriate electromagnetic parameters. With the self-assembled units transformed into needle clusters, the optimum RL value achieved by the needle array NiCo2O4 is about −45 dB and the maximum absorbing range is from 5.5 to 9 GHz, as shown in Fig. 8b. More importantly, the specific surface areas, porous property and electron accumulation of the urchin-like NiCo2O4 nanomaterials are obviously increased. Usually, the large specific surface area indicates that there are more regions in the heterogeneous interfaces that can be used to accumulate charges.46 Due to the polarization process of the electric dipole moment existing in the interfaces, the electromagnetic energy is further converted into heat energy. Benefiting from the neutralization effect, and the multiple reflection and scattering of electromagnetic waves, the absorber with a porous structure shows great potential for the efficient attenuation of electromagnetic energy. In addition, as an effective medium consisting of air and absorbing material, the reflectivity of electromagnetic waves of the porous absorbers is usually lower than that of others, which can be attributed to the improvement of impedance matching.38 Therefore, a minimum RL value of −40 dB can be obtained when the coating thickness of the urchin-like NiCo2O4 is only 1.4 mm (Fig. 8c). Due to the strong resonance peak of permittivity, the urchin-like NiCo2O4 nanomaterials also can sufficiently attenuate electromagnetic waves at a thickness of 1.5 mm in the high frequency band (12–18 GHz).
The RL maps of the NiCo2O4 nanomaterials are shown in Fig. 8d–f, which indicate that the qualified absorption of
electromagnetic wave in the range of 3–18 GHz can be obtained by changing the thickness of the electromagnetic wave absorbers. The above result is consistent with the change rule of the electromagnetic parameters of these NiCo2O4 nanomaterials. Besides, the urchin-like NiCo2O4 shows the best comprehensive electromagnetic wave absorbing capability, which is caused by the fact that the urchin-like NiCo2O4 nanomaterials are more conducive to the scattering and multiple reflection of electromagnetic waves.

to its stronger magnetic and dielectric loss. Similarly, the relative input impedance is another crucial factor to determine the electromagnetic wave absorption ability. On the basis of eqn (2), Fig. 9b shows the frequency dependence curve of impedance matching. The change trends of the relative input impedance of these NiCo2O4 absorbers are very similar. In order to adequately absorb the incident electromagnetic wave and reduce the reflectivity, it is necessary to make the relative input impedance satisfy the relation |Zin/Z0| where it is approximately equal to 1.54 As an effective medium consisting of air and absorbing materials, all of these NiCo2O4 nanomaterials with porous structures exhibit excellent impedance matching performance. Based on the above results, the urchin-like NiCo2O4 can exhibit the best electromagnetic wave absorption properties.
In order to further illustrate the excellent dielectric loss properties, the parameters related to the polarization relaxation capability of these NiCo2O4 nanomaterials are shown in Table S1.† The imaginary part of the complex permittivity (ε″) is closely related to the electromagnetic energy loss capability.39 As shown in Fig. 6, the ε″ value of the urchin-like NiCo2O4 has a strong and wide peak in the frequency range of 12.48 to 18.00 GHz, wherein the maximum ε″ value of it is 8.38. In the high frequency band, the maximum ε″ values of the bayberry-
like and needle array NiCo2O4 materials are only 4.04 and 4.20, respectively. As shown in Fig. 7, the Cole–Cole semicircles of the bayberry-like, needle array and urchin-like NiCo2O4 nanomaterials are 7, 6 and 7 respectively. Generally, each Cole–Cole semicircle corresponds to a Debye relaxation process.44 Therefore, it can be concluded that all of these materials have multiple polarization relaxation phenomena. Due to the main mechanism of electromagnetic energy attenuation being dielectric loss,8 the attenuation coefficient (α) can be used to further evaluate the polarization relaxation ability of these absorbers. As for the urchin-like NiCo2O4 material, an optimal α value of 360.82 can be successfully obtained, while that of the bayberrylike and needle array NiCo2O4 are 172.17 and 236.19, respectively. In addition, Fig. S6† shows the frequency dependence of the loss tangent (tan δε = ε″/ε′) of these materials. The maximum tan δε value of the urchin-like NiCo2O4 material is 0.84, which is much larger than that of the other materials. Generally, a larger tan δε value indicates that the material possesses stronger dielectric loss properties.21 Based on the above analysis, it can be deduced that the urchin-like NiCo2O4 has a superior polarization relaxation ability.

Hence, the existence of these semicircles usually indicates that interfacial polarization and dipole relaxation processes play an important role in the attenuation of electromagnetic waves. The accumulation of electric charges in heterogeneous interfaces and the directional arrangement of dipoles under the action of alternating electromagnetic fields can effectively consume electromagnetic energy. Furthermore, the ε″ values of these NiCo2O4 with different assembly structures show some strong and wide peaks in the whole frequency band, which also means that these NiCo2O4 materials have excellent dipole relaxation performances. Secondly, the conduction loss is also one of the crucial sources of dielectric loss. The hopping and migrating movement of conduction electrons can induce the further dissipation of electromagnetic energy. Generally, the increase of the ε″ value is closely related to the improvement of electrical conductivity. As shown in Table S1,† the average ε″ value of the urchin-like NiCo2O4 is 5.80, while that of the NiCo2O4 materials with a nano-rod and nanoneedle-like assembly organisation are 3.24 and 3.54, respectively. Besides, the tan δε value of the NiCo2O4 nanomaterials is much larger than the magnetic loss tangent (tan δμ = μ″/μ′), as shown in Fig. S6.† Therefore, it can be inferred that the excellent electromagnetic wave absorbing properties of these NiCo2O4 materials mainly result from their strong dielectric loss. Thirdly, when the frequency range is in the range of 2–11 GHz, the μ″(μ′)−2f −1 value fluctuates significantly with the frequency. Hence the natural resonance can be regarded as the main source of magnetic loss in the low frequency band. Benefiting from the excellent permeability and conductivity of these NiCo2O4 materials, large eddy currents are formed in the surface after undergoing the effect of high-frequency alternating magnetic fields. By calculating that the μ″(μ′)−2f −1 values are approximately fixed values in the high frequency band, the three NiCo2O4 materials possess a strong eddy current loss capability and can further convert electromagnetic energy into heat energy. Finally, these unique self-assembled hierarchical structures can obtain a large specific surface area and porosity. As shown in Table S2,† all the three NiCo2O4 materials possess excellent porous structures. The urchin-like NiCo2O4 obtains a specific surface area of 62.89 m
2 g−1, benefiting from the growth of a needle cluster assembly. By realizing the multiple reflection and scattering of incident electromagnetic waves, the attenuation capability of the electromagnetic wave is further enhanced. Moreover, the neutralization effect between the electromagnetic waves and inverted waves is also one of the important ways of microwave attenuation.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, bayberry-like, needle array-like and urchin-like NiCo2O4 nanomaterials were prepared and characterized. All the three nanostructured NiCo2O4 have the excellent capabil-
ity to attenuate electromagnetic energy. The urchin-like structure possesses a relatively higher specific surface area, porosity and dielectric loss ability, thereby making the optimum RL value of urchin-like NiCo2O4 reach −40 dB at a thickness of 1.4 mm, and its valid absorbing bandwidth is 4 GHz. The superior electromagnetic wave absorption properties are attributed to the enhancement of eddy current loss, and interface and dipole polarization. Moreover, as ultra-thin and efficient electromagnetic wave absorbers with broad absorbing bandwidths, the bayberry-like, needle array-like and urchinlike NiCo2O4 show bright prospects for practical applications.

metadata.abstractText: Bayberry-like, needle array-like and urchin-like NiCo2O4 hierarchical structures were synthesized by simple hydrothermal reactions. The differences among the nanostructures and morphologies affecting their electromagnetic wave absorbing properties have been systematically studied. Benefiting from the unique hierarchical structures assembled by magnetic component units, all of these NiCo2O4 nanomaterials show satisfactory performances of absorbing microwave radiation. Remarkably, the urchin-like NiCo2O4 obtains an optimum reflection loss (RL) value of −40 dB when the matching thickness is only 1.4 mm. Moreover, the urchin-like NiCo2O4 reaches an effective absorbing bandwidth of about 15 GHz upon adjustment of the coating thickness. The outstanding electromagnetic wave absorbing properties are closely related to the strong interfacial polarization, dipole relaxation, eddy current loss and multiple reflections in its unique needle-like assembly.
